important announcements.
These announcements come as
a result of the investigations.
of a special committee 'Which
was recently formed, to study
generally the conditions of the
different schools of the University.
Due to the importance of
the announcesments, all members of the undergraduate
school are expected to attend
this assembly.

The following is the final schedule of the undergraduate examinations which will begin on Monday,
May 26 and last until Tuesday,
June 3. It is of utmost importance
that every undergraduate consult
this schedule and make sure of the
time and the place of each of his
examinations.
The morning sessions begin at 9
A. M.; the afternoon sessions at 2
P. M. The time allowed is -as follows: In a three or four-hour
course, three hours; in'a one or twohour course, two hours.

The oven...
the cook...
and the cake
"Only fine ovens produce cakes of fine tex-

ture." This rule applies as surely to the most
complicated "cake-baking" process in modern
industry ... making steel castings for high
pressures... as it does to the simplest domestic
cookery. In basic-lined Heroult electric furnaces that apply the heat directly and cleanly
to the metal and permit exact control of temperatures at every stage, the steel for Crane
cast steel valves and fittings is prepared. Every
casting is annealed under temperatures held at
1600° F. for hours, then slowly shaded off
to cooling. Interesting as is the Vulcan-like
foundry equipment in Crane foundries, complete as are the manufacturing resources that
give exactness and uniformity in production,.
the vital secret back of quality in Crane electric
steel materials is not the "oven" but the skill of
the "cooks"... the chemists, the superintendents, the workmen who watch and control
each step and process. Through 75 years, this
skill has been developed and refined. Back of
it is an exhaustive scientific library of laboratory studies and test charts. Much of the data
that has enabled Crane Co. to produce dependable valves for the enormous pressures and
temperatures now used in industry is collected
in a book,"Pioneering in Science." It is a valuable reference book for students Let us send
you a copy.

The meeting was called to order
at 12.20 by President Lockard. No
old business was to be brought before the class so the duties of nominating delegates were executed. The
nominees were: Parks, Yellott,
Meeks, Towbin, Dowell, Cone.
Voting for two of these men will
take place tomorrow, Wednesday,
May 21, at 12.20 until 1 in the C. E.
Hall room 120. At this time further nominations will be held and
all withdrawals will be accepted.
After nominations were over,
John Yellott, chairman of 1931 June
Week. Committee, made an announcement concerning the coming
June Week. The meeting was adjourned at 12.35, no more business
being at hand.

TICKETS FOR U. OF M.
GAME NOW ON SALE
No student tickets will be
sold at the stadium next Saturday. All those who wish to
attend the University of Maryland-Johns Hopkins lacrosse
game must purchase their
tickets at the Athletic Office in
the basement of Remsen Hall
some time this week.
The price of these tickets is
5 Ocents plus the Athletic Association ticket. All tickets are
for the central sections of the
stadium and are not for reserved seats.
Saturday, May 24, is the
date of the game. The time is
3 o'clock, daylight saving time.

FOOTBALL MEETING
SCHEDULED THURSDAY
A meeting of all football
men will be held this Thursday at 11.30 in room 112 of
the C. E. Building.
John Heinz.erling, manager
of the team for next year,
hopes that all those men who
intend to try out for positions
of next year's eleven will be
present:
The meeting will be addressed by Coach Van Orman
who has a few important announcements to make.
All assistant managers and
Junior managers are also requested to attend the meeting
and to see Manager Heinzerling following the meeting.

INTERCOLLEGIATE
NEWS
At Haverford, they are undergoing the same dilemma which worried Hopkins last year. With the
election of the new Student Council, the question of abolition of
freshman regulations becomes pertinent. The council does not plan to
go the whole way, but there is agitation on the campus for the decisive step to be taken. If they
wish to profit by others' mistakes,
they should hold on to what rules
they have.
* * *
Announcements with regards to
hostilities between the two lower
classes at present hold an important
place in the sheets of the various
campus news vendors. Various
means of settling the disputes are
employed, and varied results are obtained. At Delaware, the sophs as
seems befitting their dignity and
worldly wisdom, defeated the frosh
in a tug-of-war, while the Purdue
wise ones were badly defeated by
the yearlings in their annual football game. Thus do the fates pull
the strings.

St. Johns' Final Efforts Futile

they had two more men sent out of

riding demon on the defense. On

Weitzel, too, played his great
game. But aboue them all Ferrarini
was stopping shots, intercepting
passes, getting loose balls, dodging
attack men and chasing the ball up
to his attack.

RUTGERS ADDED
Eight Regulars From Last
Year's Team To Return
Next year's,football schedule embraces games with eight colleges.
Five of these games will be played
at Homewood while the remaining
three will be played on the opponent's gridiron.
The Jays will not meet Syracuse,
Juniata, Richmond or Randolf-Ma, • k%
con next falr and have instituted in
their places g4n,ies with Upsala, Lehigh, Pennsylvania Military College
and Rutgers.
After the very unsuccessful season last year the Jays were quite
disheartened. The season, which
was marked by only one victory',
that over Randolf-Macon With a
score of 13-0, could not,be called a
very impressive one, but the lack of
victories could be laid • to many
causes which could not be avoided.
To begin with Bobby Lyons, the
stellar quarterback, punter, and line
gainer was ineligible due to some deficiency in his studies. Howard Caplan, who had intended returning to
the University to take up a graduate
course and whose presence would
have bolstered up the team enormously, was unable to play beacuse
he was not carrying enough •points.
The next setback that the team received was when the announcement
was made that Joe Bernard would
not be able to play because he was
black-listed. None of the things
were definitely known by the
coaches until just before the first
game on October 8, with Juniata.
The loss of these three men was
heavily felt all during the year.
Of the eleven men who made up
last year's squad, only three will be
lost by graduation. Keating, Keys
and Nickel are the three men who
will graduate. The other men, including Rosenberg, Towbin, Helm,
Bialoskorsky, Guild, Turnbull, Bledsoe and Mills will all be back next
year to fill their old positions.

The oven...
the cook...
and the cake
"Only fine ovens produce cakes of fine tex-

ture." This rule applies as surely to the most
complicated "cake-baking" process in modern
industry ... making steel castings for high
pressures... as it does to the simplest domestic
cookery. In basic-lined Heroult electric furnaces that apply the heat directly and cleanly
to the metal and permit exact control of temperatures at every stage, the steel for Crane
cast steel valves and fittings is prepared. Every
casting is annealed under temperatures held at
1600° F. for hours, then slowly shaded off
to cooling. Interesting as is the Vulcan-like
foundry equipment in Crane foundries, complete as are the manufacturing resources that
give exactness and uniformity in production,.
the vital secret back of quality in Crane electric
steel materials is not the "oven" but the skill of
the "cooks"... the chemists, the superintendents, the workmen who watch and control
each step and process. Through 75 years, this
skill has been developed and refined. Back of
it is an exhaustive scientific library of laboratory studies and test charts. Much of the data
that has enabled Crane Co. to produce dependable valves for the enormous pressures and
temperatures now used in industry is collected
in a book,"Pioneering in Science." It is a valuable reference book for students Let us send
you a copy.

The meeting was called to order
at 12.20 by President Lockard. No
old business was to be brought before the class so the duties of nominating delegates were executed. The
nominees were: Parks, Yellott,
Meeks, Towbin, Dowell, Cone.
Voting for two of these men will
take place tomorrow, Wednesday,
May 21, at 12.20 until 1 in the C. E.
Hall room 120. At this time further nominations will be held and
all withdrawals will be accepted.
After nominations were over,
John Yellott, chairman of 1931 June
Week. Committee, made an announcement concerning the coming
June Week. The meeting was adjourned at 12.35, no more business
being at hand.

TICKETS FOR U. OF M.
GAME NOW ON SALE
No student tickets will be
sold at the stadium next Saturday. All those who wish to
attend the University of Maryland-Johns Hopkins lacrosse
game must purchase their
tickets at the Athletic Office in
the basement of Remsen Hall
some time this week.
The price of these tickets is
5 Ocents plus the Athletic Association ticket. All tickets are
for the central sections of the
stadium and are not for reserved seats.
Saturday, May 24, is the
date of the game. The time is
3 o'clock, daylight saving time.

FOOTBALL MEETING
SCHEDULED THURSDAY
A meeting of all football
men will be held this Thursday at 11.30 in room 112 of
the C. E. Building.
John Heinz.erling, manager
of the team for next year,
hopes that all those men who
intend to try out for positions
of next year's eleven will be
present:
The meeting will be addressed by Coach Van Orman
who has a few important announcements to make.
All assistant managers and
Junior managers are also requested to attend the meeting
and to see Manager Heinzerling following the meeting.

INTERCOLLEGIATE
NEWS
At Haverford, they are undergoing the same dilemma which worried Hopkins last year. With the
election of the new Student Council, the question of abolition of
freshman regulations becomes pertinent. The council does not plan to
go the whole way, but there is agitation on the campus for the decisive step to be taken. If they
wish to profit by others' mistakes,
they should hold on to what rules
they have.
* * *
Announcements with regards to
hostilities between the two lower
classes at present hold an important
place in the sheets of the various
campus news vendors. Various
means of settling the disputes are
employed, and varied results are obtained. At Delaware, the sophs as
seems befitting their dignity and
worldly wisdom, defeated the frosh
in a tug-of-war, while the Purdue
wise ones were badly defeated by
the yearlings in their annual football game. Thus do the fates pull
the strings.

St. Johns' Final Efforts Futile

The St. Johns men became wild
in their efforts to tie up the score
they had two more men sent out of
the game. With this advantage,
and the Jay defense covering their
men all over the field, the ball remained in the visiting team's end of
the field until the final whistle.
During all the game Packard had
been playing as he had never played
before. He got all but one or two
of the draws at center and was a
riding demon on the defense. On
the attack he kept the St. Johns defense worried all the time.
Weitzel, too, played his great
game. But aboue them all Ferrarini
was stopping shots, intercepting
passes, getting loose balls, dodging
attack men and chasing the ball up
to his attack.
Attack Has Fine Record

The attack merits mention. They
had the ball in enemy territory for
not more than fifteen minutes of the
whole game. They had not more
than eight shots in these fifteen
minutes and ma'de three of them
goad.

RUTGERS ADDED
Eight Regulars From Last
Year's Team To Return
Next year's,football schedule embraces games with eight colleges.
Five of these games will be played
at Homewood while the remaining
three will be played on the opponent's gridiron.
The Jays will not meet Syracuse,
Juniata, Richmond or Randolf-Ma, • k%
con next falr and have instituted in
their places g4n,ies with Upsala, Lehigh, Pennsylvania Military College
and Rutgers.
After the very unsuccessful season last year the Jays were quite
disheartened. The season, which
was marked by only one victory',
that over Randolf-Macon With a
score of 13-0, could not,be called a
very impressive one, but the lack of
victories could be laid • to many
causes which could not be avoided.
To begin with Bobby Lyons, the
stellar quarterback, punter, and line
gainer was ineligible due to some deficiency in his studies. Howard Caplan, who had intended returning to
the University to take up a graduate
course and whose presence would
have bolstered up the team enormously, was unable to play beacuse
he was not carrying enough •points.
The next setback that the team received was when the announcement
was made that Joe Bernard would
not be able to play because he was
black-listed. None of the things
were definitely known by the
coaches until just before the first
game on October 8, with Juniata.
The loss of these three men was
heavily felt all during the year.
Of the eleven men who made up
last year's squad, only three will be
lost by graduation. Keating, Keys
and Nickel are the three men who
will graduate. The other men, including Rosenberg, Towbin, Helm,
Bialoskorsky, Guild, Turnbull, Bledsoe and Mills will all be back next
year to fill their old positions.
